hints.content: Start by understanding the concept of palindromic numbers. A palindromic number reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 121 and 1331 are palindromic, while 123 is not.
Consider the range of palindromic numbers you can use. The problem states that these numbers must be less than 10^9. Think about how many palindromic numbers fall within this range.
Remember that you can change any element in the array to any positive integer x, but the goal is to change all elements to a single palindromic number y. What strategy could minimize the total cost?

To calculate the cost of changing all elements to a specific palindromic number y, use the formula: total cost = sum(|nums[i] - y|) for all i. This will help you evaluate different palindromic targets.
You might want to generate a list of palindromic numbers up to 10^9. Consider using a function that constructs palindromic numbers by mirroring digits.

When calculating costs for different palindromic targets, note that the optimal palindromic number may not always be the median of the array. Think about how the distribution of your nums affects the cost.
Edge cases are important. What happens if all elements in nums are already the same? How does this affect the cost calculation? Consider how this simplifies your approach.
If you find multiple palindromic numbers that yield the same minimum cost, think about how you would handle ties. Is there a specific way to choose among them?
As you iterate through potential palindromic targets, keep track of the minimum cost encountered. Use a variable to store this value and update it whenever you find a lower cost.
Finally, ensure your solution efficiently handles the maximum constraints. With n up to 10^5, consider the time complexity of generating palindromic numbers and calculating costs.

questionNotes: All elements must be changed to the same palindromic number.
Palindromic numbers must be positive integers less than 10^9.
